University Xi’an 710129 China * leiwang@cumt.edu.cn * zhuhongyou@nwpu.edu.cn * xaycq@163.com 12 9 2025 23 9 2025 10 37 497498 43187 43200 14 7 2025 08 9 2025 22 8 2025 12 9 2025 12 09 2025 26 09 2025 29 09 2025 © 2025 The Authors. Published by American Chemical Society 2025 The Authors https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ This article is licensed under CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 Circular RNAs (circRNAs) possess structural stability
and tissue-specific
expression patterns, making them potential disease biomarkers. Exploring
the associations between circRNAs and diseases is crucial for early
diagnosis and targeted treatment. However, due to the complexity of
biological relationships and the presence of multisource heterogeneous
data, traditional prediction methods often face challenges such as
insufficient information integration, limited semantic expression,
and information loss. To address these challenges, this paper proposes
a computational model, MTGCDA, based on a multisource heterogeneous
graph transformer for high-accuracy prediction of circRNA-disease
associations. Specifically, MTGCDA first integrates multisource biological
information about circRNAs and diseases, constructing a heterogeneous
graph containing multiple node types and multiple edge relationships.
Representation learning of the graph structure is performed using
a heterogeneous graph neural network, fully exploiting the latent
semantic features of different node types. The model then fuses the
embeddings of circRNA and disease nodes in a multilayer heterogeneous
graph convolutional network to construct a joint feature representation,
which is then fed into a CatBoost classifier to accurately score circRNA-disease
associations. Experimental results on the CircR2Disease data set demonstrate
that the MTGCDA model achieves an AUC of 0.9756, significantly outperforming
several existing methods. At the same time, among the 20 selected
circRNA-disease association pairs, 17 pairs were verified by literature
reports, further demonstrating the high accuracy of the model in predicting
potential associations and its biological practicality. closed RNA molecule formed
by reverse splicing and is abundant in eukaryotes.           With the continuous deepening of
circRNA research, a large amount
of circRNA-related disease data has been continuously accumulated.    These
methods integrate a variety of biological information to
accurately predict potential circRNA-disease associations, thereby
promoting in-depth research and application of circRNA in the biomedical
field. For example, in the network analysis-based method, Lei et al. In order to address the challenges of circRNA-disease association
prediction and improve the prediction performance, we proposed a new
computational method, MTGCDA. This method is based on a multilayer
heterogeneous graph encoder with a Transformer structure, which aims
to capture the potential association between circRNA and disease.
In the model design, we first aggregate multisource information into
circRNA and disease nodes to construct an initial feature representation,
and further aggregate and update the features through a multilayer
heterogeneous graph encoder. Subsequently, the circRNA and disease
embedding features extracted from each layer are spliced to maximize
information retention. In the decoding stage, we use the spliced features
as the input of the CatBoost classifier for the association prediction
task. To verify the effectiveness of the model, we conducted 5-fold
cross-validation (5-CV) on the benchmark data set and conducted a
comprehensive comparison with 8 advanced methods. Figure Introducing biological meta-pathway information: In
order to better capture the diverse associations between circRNA and
diseases, the MTGCDA framework effectively integrates biological meta-pathway
information. This innovative design enables the model to learn the
complex relationship between circRNA and disease at different biological
levels, significantly improving the model’s ability to predict
potential unknown associations. Application
of multilayer heterogeneous encoders: This
model uses multilayer heterogeneous encoders to capture different
types of associations. Through this deep feature aggregation strategy,
the model can fuse information at different levels, enhance the ability
to characterize circRNA-disease relationships, and effectively improve
the accuracy and generalization of predictions. Deep fusion of embedded information: Considering the
advantages of CatBoost in processing embedded features, we use it
as a decoder to process the circRNA-disease feature splicing matrix,
further optimizing the performance of the model. This design ensures
efficient fusion of information and enhances the accuracy and stability
of the model. 1 Schematic diagram of the MTGCDA framework. (a) Multisource information
construction and fusion: This integrates multisource biological information
about circRNAs and diseases and constructs a heterogeneous graph.
(b) Transformer heterogeneous graph representation learning: This
extracts latent semantic features from different node types through
a heterogeneous graph neural network. (c) Classifier association prediction:
This embeds the fused nodes into a CatBoost classifier to accurately
score the association between circRNAs and diseases. Methods Data Set As people’s research on the association
between circRNA and diseases deepens, many public databases have been
constructed. We constructed four circRNA-disease association data
sets from many databases, namely CircR2Disease,    Table 1 Dataset Details Database CircRNA Disease Associated CircR2Disease 561 100 607 CircAtlas 708 117 775 Circ2Disease 234 60 254 CircRNADisease 286 48 304 Similarity Feature Extraction Based on circRNA and Disease In our experiments, the similarities constructed using circRNA
data include circRNA functional similarity, circRNA sequence similarity,
and Gaussian kernel similarity. The similarities constructed using
disease data include Gaussian kernel similarity and disease semantic
similarity. Disease Semantic Similarity Construction In order to
measure the semantic similarity between diseases, we obtained the
MeSH vocabulary of disease ontology markers from the MeSH disease
database and constructed a directed acyclic graph (DAG) by obtaining
disease semantic information to reveal the association between different
diseases. When constructing a DAG d N  d E  d d DAG  d d N  d E  d DAG DAG d D d s 1 { D d ( s ) = 1 i f s = d D d ( s ) = max { μ · D d ( s ′ ) | s ′ ∈ c h i l d r e n o f s ) i f s ≠ d In the above formula, μ d DV d 2 D V ( d ) = ∑ s ∈ N d D d ( s ) According to the above calculation

calculation method based on known interaction information. Based on
existing research, in this study, we use GIP kernel similarity to
measure the similarity between circRNA and disease. We construct disease
similarity models based on adjacency matrices and circRNA models based
on adjacency matrices, respectively. The adjacency matrices are obtained
from known association relationships. When constructing the interaction
representation between diseases, an V d i d i 4 D G I P ( d ( i ) , d ( j ) ) = exp ( − θ d ∥ V ( d ( i ) ) − V ( d ( j ) ) ∥ 2 ) 5 θ d = 1 m ∑ i = 1 m ∥ V ( d ( i ) ) ∥ 2 6 C G I P ( c ( i ) , c ( j ) ) = exp ( − θ c ∥ V ( c ( i ) ) − V ( c ( j ) ) ∥ 2 ) 7 θ c = 1 n ∑ i = 1 n ∥ V ( c ( i ) ) ∥ 2 In the above formula, θ  c θ d m n Constructing circRNA Functional Similarity Using Semantic Relationships The construction of circRNA functional similarity comprehensively
considers the similarity contribution of its associated diseases.
Based on the method proposed by Wang et al., assuming that there are
two semantically identical diseases and both are associated with a
certain circRNA, then the circRNA may have similar functions to the
circRNA associated with the disease. Based on this hypothesis, two
different circRNAs are given, represented by c i c j D i D j d i d j C FS c i c j 8 C F S ( c ( i ) , c ( j ) ) = ∑ 1 ≤ i ≤ | D ( i ) | S ( d ( i ) , D ( j ) ) + ∑ 1 ≤ j ≤ | D ( j ) | S ( d ( j ) , D ( i ) ) | D ( i ) | + | D ( j ) | 9 S ( d ( i ) , D ( j ) ) = max 1 ≤ k ≤ | D ( j ) | ( D S ( d ( i ) , d ( k ) ) ) Constructing circRNA Sequence Similarity Based on PCC In order to quantify the similarity between different circRNAs, the
PCC method was used to measure the sequence similarity between circRNAs. k u v 10 C P S ( u , v ) = ∑ i = 1 n u i − u̅ ∑ i = 1 n v i − v̅ ∑ i = 1 n ( u i − u̅ ) 2 ∑ i = 1 n ( v i − v̅ ) 2 Where n  u̅ = 1 n ∑ i = 1 n u i  v̅ = 1 n ∑ i = 1 n v i Multisource Heterogeneous Similarity Information Fusion In order to enhance the information richness of similarity, we fuse
multiple similarity information. Specifically, after constructing
different similarity matrices, we use a multisimilarity fusion strategy
to integrate the similarity information on circRNA and diseases. This
method can effectively reduce the limitations of a single feature,
make full use of the features of different data sources, and improve
the comprehensiveness of similarity measurement. In terms of
circRNAs, their similarity is represented by C  FUS c i c j C FUS 11 C F U S ( c ( i ) , c ( j ) ) = { C F S ( c ( i ) , c ( j ) ) if c ( i ) and c ( j ) exist C G I P ( c ( i ) , c ( j ) ) otherwise Similarly, we adopt the same fusion
strategy when constructing
the disease similarity information representation. Let the disease

information fusion method
to construct the circRNA fusion similarity network ( C  FUS D  FUS Construction of Multilayer Heterogeneous Graph Transformer Traditional heterogeneous graph models are difficult to characterize
complex dynamic relationships, while the Transformer-based multilayer
heterogeneous graph can achieve adaptive modeling and accurately capture
the deep associations of heterogeneous data through relationship-aware
self-attention and relationship-specific parametrization, thereby
improving expression and generalization capabilities. Therefore, this
multilayer heterogeneous graph is used for node representation learning
to accurately capture the complex association characteristics and
deep interaction patterns between circRNA and diseases. Here, we first
need to calculate the heterogeneous mutual attention. Since the target
node circRNA and the source node disease are connected through a heterogeneous
graph, in order to effectively transfer information, it is necessary
to calculate the attention weight between the target node circRNA
and its adjacent disease node. This weight reflects the role of the
disease node in updating the circRNA node representation during the
information aggregation process. have different effects
on the target node, μ τ n d ϕ e d  c τ n c n  c h 20 M e s s a g e H G T ( n d , e d , c , n c ) = P i ∈ [ l , e t h ] M S G − h e a d i ( n d , e d , c , n c ) 21 M S G − h e a d i ( n c , e c , m , n c ) = M − L i n e a r τ ( n c ) i ( e ( l − 1 ) [ n c ] ) W ϕ ( e d , c ) M S G In the above formula,  M − L i n e a r τ ( n d ) i  W ϕ ( e d , c ) M S G e d  c (  l ) n c 22 e ( l ) [ n c ] = A − L i n e a r τ ( n c ) ( σ ( ẽ ( l ) [ n c ] ) ) + e ( l − 1 ) [ n c ] 23 e ( l ) [ n d ] = A − L i n e a r τ ( n d ) ( σ ( ẽ ( l ) [ n d ] ) ) + e ( l − 1 ) [ n d ] Association Prediction The circRNAs extracted from
the multilayer heterogeneous encoders were spliced with disease signatures
to construct a comprehensive representation of circRNA-disease associations
as shown below: 24 Z i j = [ F c ( i ) , F d ( j ) ] Among them, F c i i th F  c F d j j th F  d Results and Discussion Evaluation Indicators In order to measure the performance
of the proposed method MTGCDA in prediction tasks to a certain extent,
we introduced multiple evaluation indicators to cover the responsiveness
of the model at different decision-making levels. Specifically, they
include: Accuracy (ACC), Precision, Recall, F1-score, and Specificity.
The specific calculation is as follows: A c c u r a c y = T P + T N T P + T N + F P + F N P r e c i s i o n = T P T P + F P R e c a l l = T P T P + F N F 1 = 2 · P r e c i s i o n · R e c a l l P r e c i s i o n + R e c a l l S p e c i f i c i t y = T N T N + F P Among them, TP TN FP TN Empirical Analysis of MTGCDA through 5-CV In order
to systematically evaluate the stability and generalization performance
of the proposed method, we used 5-CV for training and testing in all
experiments. In the experiment, we evenly divided the complete sample
set into five subsets, selected one of the subsets as the test set
in each iteration, and the remaining four groups were used for model
training. This cycle was repeated five times to ensure that each subset
could participate in one evaluation as test data. The final experimental
results were measured by the average of the five evaluation results
to minimize the interference of chance on model performance. In the
sample construction process, considering that the number of verified
associations between circRNA and disease is far less than that of
unknown association pairs, if all unobserved associations are directly
equated as negative samples, a large number of potential true positive
samples may be introduced, resulting in label errors and interference
with model training. Therefore, in each cross-validation partition,
we regarded the known circRNA-disease pairs in the database as positive
samples, and randomly selected an equal number of pairs from unknown
associations as negative samples. This strategy not only balances
the ratio of positive and negative samples and avoids the bias of
the model due to class imbalance, but also effectively reduces noise
interference and improves the quality and effectiveness of training
data. Through such a sample construction and evaluation mechanism,
not only the robustness of the model in the training stage is enhanced,
but also its generalization ability on unknown data is improved, laying
a solid foundation for subsequent association prediction tasks. During the model training process, we reasonably configured various
key parameters to ensure the stability of the model performance and
the efficiency of the training process. All experiments were completed
under the same hardware environment. We set the initial learning rate
to 0.001 and the weight decay coefficient to 1 × 10 –5 Figure 2 Evaluation of the prediction performance of
the MTGCDA model based
on 5-CV. The 5-fold validation results of the experiment
are shown in Table 2 Comprehensive Prediction Performance
Evaluation of MTGCDA Model under 5-CV Test set AUC AUPR F1 (%) ACC (%) Recall
(%) Specificity (%) Precision (%) 1 0.9832 0.9787 95.04 95.06 98.29 92.06 92.50 2 0.9819 0.9764 96.41 96.30 96.03 96.58 96.80 3 0.9683 0.9306 94.86 94.65 99.17 90.16 92.91 4 0.9705 0.9633 94.30 93.83 99.20 88.14 89.86 5 0.9740 0.9506 95.04 95.04 97.46 92.74 92.74 Average 0.9756 0.9599 95.13 94.98 98.03 91.94 92.96 Evaluation of the Impact of Multiview Integration on Model Performance In order to further verify the effectiveness of various views in
this model and explore the impact of different view combinations on
prediction performance, we designed a series of combination experiments.
The main features involved in the experiment include circRNA functional
similarity (C_fun), sequence similarity (C_Se), GIP nuclear similarity
(C_GIP and D_GIP) and semantic similarity of diseases (D_SE). During
the experiment, different features were combined in multiple ways,
and the prediction ability of the combined model of different features
was evaluated by inputting different combinations of these views into
the model. The experimental results are shown in Figure 3 Performance comparison
of multiview information fusion strategies
in MTGCDA model. From the experimental results, we can see that
the combination
C_fun + C_GIP + C_Seq + D_GIP + D_SE achieved the best results, with
AUC of 0.9756, AUPR of 0.9599, F1 score of 95.13%, ACC of 94.98%,
Recall of 98.03%, Specificity of 91.94%, and Precision of 92.96%.
This combination performed best in indicators such as AUC, AUPR, F1,
and ACC, indicating that the various features in the combination have
a synergistic effect in improving the predictive performance of the
model and can effectively enhance the model’s ability to predict
the association between circRNA and disease. In contrast, although
the combinations C_fun + C_GIP + D_GIP +
D_SE and C_fun + C_Seq + D_GIP + D_SE also performed well in some
indicators, they failed to surpass the optimal combination overall.
Specifically, although the AUC and AUPR of the combination of C_fun
+ C_GIP + D_GIP + D_SE also reached a high level (0.9619 and 0.9478
respectively), the F1 score and ACC dropped slightly, indicating that
the combination has certain deficiencies in some evaluation dimensions.
This shows that the advantages of a single feature may be difficult
to fully exert in all dimensions, and the complementarity of multiple
feature combinations is crucial to improving performance. We further
explored the complementarity of features and their impact on enhancing
the generalization ability of the model. The Impact of Different Feature Dimensions on Model Performance In order to further evaluate the impact of feature dimensions on
model prediction performance, we designed experiments under different
dimension settings to compare and analyze the performance of the model
on multiple indicators. In this experiment, while keeping other parameters
unchanged, the feature dimensions were set to 16, 32, 64, 128, 256,
and 512 respectively, and 5-fold cross validation was used to obtain
the average performance index. The experimental results are shown
in Figure 4 Impact of feature
dimension on the prediction performance of MTGCDA
model. Experimental results show that model performance
steadily improves
with increasing feature dimensionality at low dimensionality. When
the feature dimension increases from 16 to 128, the model shows significant
improvements across all metrics, including AUC (from 0.9446 to 0.9756),
AUPR (from 0.9290 to 0.9599), and F1-score (F1-value) and ACC (accuracy)
reaching 95.13% and 94.98%, respectively. This suggests that at low
dimensionality, the model’s ability to capture the characteristic
information associated with circRNAs and diseases is limited, and
a moderate increase in feature dimensionality can help more comprehensively
characterize potential associations. However, when the dimensionality
is further increased to 256 and 512, model performance decreases.
At 256 dimensionality, the AUC drops to 0.9364 and the AUPR to 0.9036,
both lower than the results with 128 dimensionality. This suggests
that excessively high feature dimensionality may introduce redundant
information or noise, disrupting the model during training and affecting
prediction accuracy and generalization. Overall, the experimental
results suggest that a trade-off should be made between information
representation ability and redundant noise when selecting feature
dimensions to obtain the best prediction performance. Impact of MTGCDA Model Structure Hyperparameters on Performance In order to further explore the impact of model structural hyperparameters
on performance, this paper designs an ablation experiment on the number
of attention heads and network layers in the multihead attention mechanism.
Through the control variable method, under the premise of fixing other
parameter configurations, the number of attention heads and network
layers are systematically adjusted to evaluate their specific impact
on model performance, so as to optimize the model structure design
and improve its generalization and expression capabilities. In the experiment of the number of attention heads, we set 2, 4,
8, 16, 32, and 64 heads respectively, and evaluated their performance
in multiple indicators such as AUC, AUPR, F1, ACC, Recall, Specificity
and Precision. The experimental results are shown in Figure 5 Impact of varying the
number of attention heads on the performance
of MTGCDA. The experimental results show that the model performance
is optimal
when the number of attention heads is 4, at which time AUC and AUPR
are 0.9756 and 0.9599 respectively, and the F1 value also reaches
0.9513, showing good stability and accuracy. As the number of attention
heads increases, the overall model performance shows a downward trend.
The reason is that the multihead mechanism introduces too much redundant
attention distribution, which dilutes the effective representation
and makes it difficult for the model to focus on key semantic dependency
features, which in turn weakens the discrimination ability. In the setting of the number of network layers, we increase the
model depth from 1 layer to 8 layers to observe its impact on representation
learning ability and prediction performance. The experimental results
are as Figure 6 Performance
comparison of MTGCDA model with different number of
structural layers. The results show that as the number of layers increases,
the overall
model performance shows a steady upward trend until it reaches the
optimal level at 5 layers, when all indicators perform best (AUC is
0.9756, AUPR is 0.9599). This shows that moderately deepening the
network helps capture more complex high-order feature associations
and enhances the modeling ability of potential circRNA-disease associations.
However, after more than 5 layers, the model performance fluctuates
and falls back, especially in indicators such as F1 and Precision.
This phenomenon may be caused by problems such as gradient disappearance,
redundant feature stacking, and overfitting brought by deep networks,
which affects the generalization performance of the model on the test
set. In summary, when the number of attention heads is set to 4 and
the number of network layers is set to 5, the model performs best
in all performance indicators, showing good robustness and generalization
ability. Comparative Analysis of Multiple Classifiers under the MTGCDA
Framework In order to comprehensively evaluate the adaptability
and stability of the proposed method under different classifier architectures,
this paper compares the performance of various mainstream classification
models based on the unified feature representation input, including
support vector machine (SVM), logistic regression (LR), CatBoost,
extra trees (ET), AdaBoost, gradient boosting (GB), histogram-based
gradient boosting (HGB), decision tree (DT) and Gaussian naive Bayes
(NB). The index comparison is shown in Figure Table 7 Comparative
analysis of the performance of various classifiers
in the MTGCDA model. 3 Experimental Results of Different
Classifiers classifier AUC AUPR F1 (%) ACC (%) Recall
(%) Specificity (%) Precision (%) SVM 0.8035 0.6733 88.55 87.15 99.33 74.96 79.93 LR 0.8250 0.7258 84.88 83.03 95.64 70.28 76.36 CatBoost 0.9756 0.9599 95.13 94.98 98.03 91.94 92.96 ET 0.9447 0.9409 89.55 89.13 93.36 84.83 86.08 Adaboost 0.7318 0.6580 75.15 69.44 92.53 46.22 63.30 GB 0.9247 0.9114 88.08 87.23 94.41 80.14 82.60 HGB 0.9247 0.9042 87.85 86.90 94.64 79.31 82.14 DT 0.8817 0.8472 86.74 85.34 96.01 74.56 79.15 NB 0.7727 0.7947 76.30 72.32 89.28 55.39 66.74 The experimental results show that the CatBoost classifier
has
achieved the best performance in almost all evaluation indicators,
and its performance is significantly higher than other classifiers.
This shows that CatBoost has shown strong adaptability and generalization
capabilities in dealing with high-dimensional sparse features, modeling
nonlinear relationships, and coping with data imbalance problems,
verifying its rationality as the core classification component of
this study. Among other ensemble learning methods, Extra Trees and
Gradient Boosting also performed well. The former is highly competitive
in AUC and AUPR, and the latter has also reached a high level in multiple
indicators. This shows that classifiers based on ensemble mechanisms
have significant advantages over traditional methods in modeling complex
feature interactions. In contrast, although traditional linear classifiers
such as SVM and Logistic Regression perform well in Recall rate, their
overall recognition ability is limited and it is difficult to fully
capture complex nonlinear distribution features. The weak classifier
NB performed poorly in this task, indicating that its ability to model
high-dimensional complex biological data is limited. In summary, CatBoost
not only achieves the best results in key indicators such as Precision,
Recall, and F1 value, but also has strong model stability and generalization
ability. It is the most suitable classifier choice for the current
task. Comparison with Other Models In recent years, with
the continuous deepening of circRNA research, many computational methods
have been proposed to efficiently predict circRNA-disease associations
(CDA) and have achieved good results. In order to further comprehensively
evaluate the effectiveness and advancement of the MTGCDA model proposed
by us, this paper systematically compares it with the current mainstream
circRNA-disease association prediction methods, including SATPIC2CD, Table 4 Comparison of Results from Different
Models Methods AUC Recall ACC F1 SATPIC2CD 0.9728 0.9703 0.4976 0.017 HGCNCDA 0.9491 0.5137  0.9920 0.5532 Bi-SGTAR 0.8747 0.8759 0.4965 0.0107 RPMVCDA 0.9518 0.9115 0.9378 0.911 EELMCDA 0.9291 0.8705 0.924 0.9194 MNDCDA 0.9070 0.4874 0.9612 0.0509 ICDFGF 0.9572 0.9104 0.9012 0.9029 ELCDA 0.9289 0.8320 0.8560 0.852 MTGCDA  0.97558  0.9803 0.94976  0.9513 To further assess the differences in predictive performance
between
models, we performed a statistical analysis on the results. The obtained
p-value was 0.0215, below the 0.05 threshold, suggesting that the
null hypothesis of no performance difference can be rejected. This
indicates that the models show statistically significant variations
in their predictive capabilities. Validation on an Independent Data Set To further validate
the generalization performance of the proposed method, we conducted
experiments on the Circ2Disease independent data set. This data set
was not used in the model training process and effectively evaluates
the model’s adaptability to unseen samples. During the experiment,
the model parameters were consistent with those in the main experiment,
and the same evaluation metrics were used for comparative analysis.
The experimental results are shown in Table 5 Verification of Experimental Results
on Dataset Circ2Disease Test set AUC AUPR F1 (%) ACC (%) Recall
(%) Specificity (%) Precision (%) 1 0.9046 0.8776 87.93 86.27 98.08 74.01 79.69 2 0.9393 0.8852 90.53 91.18 91.49 90.91 89.58 3 0.8785 0.8309 88.70 87.25 99.17 74.51 79.69 4 0.9784 0.9706 93.58 93.07 99.20 86.01 87.93 5 0.9517 0.9579 89.72 89.11 90.57 87.50 88.89 Average 0.9305 0.9045 90.09 89.38 95.70 82.58 85.16 The experimental results show that the model also
achieves excellent
predictive performance on this independent data set. Metrics such
as AUC, AUPR, F1 score, and ACC are similar to or slightly better
than those on the main data set, demonstrating that the model can
effectively capture the potential associations between circRNAs and
diseases in different data environments. Case Study To further verify the reliability and practical
application ability of the proposed model MTGCDA in identifying potential
circRNA-disease associations, this paper conducted a case study based
on real data. Specifically, we regarded all known circRNA-disease
associations as positive samples, and randomly selected association
pairs equal to the number of positive samples from unknown associations
as negative samples to construct a training set. After the model was
trained on this sample set, it predicted all unknown circRNA-disease
combinations and output the corresponding association scores. The
higher the score, the greater the possibility that the combination
is a potential true association ( Table 6 20 High-Confidence Disease-Related
circRNAs Predicted by the Model  CircRNA Disease PMID 1 circ-ABCB10 Colorectal Cancer 33902207 2 hsa_circ_0000144 urinary bladder cancer 30098434 3 hsa_cire_0007385 Lung Cancer 29372377 4 circPVT1 acute myeloid leukemia 36718632 5 mmu_circRNA_017963 Alzheimer
disease 29448241 6 Circ_BEND6 hepatocellular carcinoma Unconfirmed 7 mmu_circRNA_006229 Alzheimer disease 29448241 8 hsa_circ_0016760 Liver Cancer 29440731 9 circANRIL atherosclerosis 35497183 10 hsa_circ_0001946 urinary bladder cancer 29694981 11 Cir-ITCH liver cancer Unconfirmed 12 hsa_circ_0001141 Stomach Cancer 33060778 13 circHIPK3 urinary bladder cancer 37269429 14 hsa_circ_0004458 Gastric Cancer 28544609 15 Circ_SLC8A1 urinary bladder cancer 31228937 16 mmu_circRNA_012180 Alzheimer
disease 29448241 17 circRNA_ 010567 Colon Cancer Unconfirmed 18 hsa_circ_0007158 urinary bladder cancer 27484176 19 hsa_circ_0004214 Cervical Cancer 28622299 20 has_circ_0006633 Gastric Cancer 28656881 Based on this, we selected several circRNA-disease
combinations
with high model prediction scores for in-depth analysis. These predictions
were then empirically validated by searching relevant literature in
the PubMed database. The results demonstrated that these high-confidence
predictions were supported by existing experimental literature, further
demonstrating the applicability and predictive power of the MTGCDA
model in real-world biological scenarios. Furthermore, we identified
20 circRNA-disease associations with high potential for research.
These results were not only applied to the model training process,
but also demonstrated biological plausibility in recent studies of
disease mechanisms. Among them, circ-ABCB10 may play a role in colorectal
cancer by regulating the expression of genes involved in cancer cell
proliferation and migration, while hsa_circ_0000144 has been found
to regulate the proliferation and invasiveness of bladder cancer cells.
Overexpression of circPVT1 is closely associated with drug resistance
and prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia, potentially promoting tumor
progression by regulating key oncogenic signaling pathways. Regarding
the neurodegenerative disease-associated mmu_circRNA_017963, it is
implicated in regulating neuronal apoptosis and synaptic function
in Alzheimer’s disease models, suggesting its potential role
in disease progression. circANRIL, a potential regulator of atherosclerosis,
may exert its effects by influencing vascular smooth muscle cell apoptosis
and inflammatory responses. For the predicted associations that have
not yet been experimentally validated, circ_BEND6 with hepatocellular
carcinoma, Cir-ITCH with liver cancer, and circRNA_010567 with colon
cancer, these are identified as important candidate targets for future
experimental validation. Based on their prediction scores, they are
speculated to participate in disease progression by regulating cancer-related
signaling pathways and cell cycle-related genes. This discovery
demonstrates the excellent generalization performance
and potential for biological knowledge mining of MTGCDA, providing
valuable candidate targets and theoretical foundations for subsequent
experimental research. These results further validate the feasibility
and effectiveness of MTGCDA in practical applications and demonstrate
its powerful ability to uncover potential circRNA-disease associations.
This model can not only help researchers efficiently screen candidate
associations with biological significance, but also provide solid
theoretical support and predictive tools for exploring the mechanisms
of disease occurrence and developing new biomarkers. Conclusions In recent years, a large number of studies
have shown that circRNA
plays a key regulatory role in the occurrence and development of diseases.
Therefore, building an efficient and accurate prediction model to
identify potential circRNA-disease associations is of great significance
for disease mechanism research and target discovery. This paper proposes
a novel multisource heterogeneous graph joint attention mechanism
model MTGCDA to systematically mine potential circRNA-disease associations.
MTGCDA integrates a variety of biological feature information, including
sequence similarity, functional annotations, semantic hierarchical
relationships, and GIP kernel similarity, constructs a multisource
heterogeneous graph, and introduces an attention mechanism to dynamically
model the importance of feature channels, thereby accurately capturing
complex biological relationships. Experimental results show
that MTGCDA performs significantly better
than existing mainstream methods on multiple real data sets, and achieves
leading results in indicators such as AUC, AUPR, and F1, verifying
its effectiveness in feature fusion and representation learning. Parameter
sensitivity analysis and ablation experiments further confirm the
core value of the multisource heterogeneous structure and attention
mechanism in the model. At the same time, the case study section demonstrates
the application potential of MTGCDA in actual circRNA-disease association
mining, in which several high-scoring prediction pairs have been confirmed
in the literature, indicating that this method not only has good generalization
ability, but also has strong biological explanatory power. Although
MTGCDA has achieved satisfactory results, the heterogeneous
graph constructed by the current model has not yet covered more potential
types of biological information, and there is still room for further
expansion. Although MTGCDA performs well in integrating multisource
features and predicting circRNA-disease associations, the model still
has several limitations: First, it relies heavily on the integrity
and quality of the input data, and prediction accuracy may be affected
when data is missing or noisy. Second, the model has high computational
cost and memory consumption when processing large-scale data or high-dimensional
features, and it does not fully model the complex nonlinear relationships
between features. Future research can further explore meta-pathway
design, graph structure expansion, and cross-modal information fusion
to enhance the model’s ability to express and explain complex
disease mechanisms, providing stronger theoretical support and practical
tools for circRNA-related research. The authors thank the Guangxi Science and Technology

Identification of circRNA-disease associations via
